message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and laboratory findings suggest acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is known to have a balanced translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17. Myeloperoxidase is a specific marker for myeloid cells and is positive in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and laboratory findings are consistent with acute promyelocytic leukemia. This type of leukemia is characterized by a balanced translocation between the long arms of chromosome 15 and 17, resulting in a fusion gene known as PML-RARA. Immature cells in the bone marrow from patients with APL, known as promyelocytes, stain positive for myeloperoxidase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient’s symptoms and laboratory studies suggest acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is associated with the translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17. APL cells stain positive for myeloperoxidase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is characterized by a balanced translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17. The leukemic cells in this type of leukemia stain positive for myeloperoxidase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and laboratory studies suggest a diagnosis of acute promyelocytic leukemia, which is associated with a balanced translocation between the long arms of chromosome 15 and 17. These leukemic cells are most likely to stain positive for myeloperoxidase.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and laboratory findings suggest acute leukemia. Among the options, myeloperoxidase is the most commonly used stain to identify myeloid cells in the diagnosis of acute leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and laboratory findings are consistent with acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL). The characteristic genetic abnormality of APL is a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17, which leads to the formation of the abnormal fusion protein PML-RARA. Leukemic cells in APL typically stain positive for myeloperoxidase, making option (A) the correct answer. Option (B) is associated with hairy cell leukemia, option (C) is associated with glycogen storage diseases, and option (D) is associated with acute lymphoblastic leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presenting symptoms and laboratory tests suggest the patient has acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), which is characterized by a balanced translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17. Myeloperoxidase is a marker for myeloid cells, which are abundant in APL. Terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferase is a marker for lymphoid cells and is not typically expressed in myeloid leukemia. Tartrate resistant acid phosphatase and periodic acid-Schiff are not specific markers for any type of leukemia.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The presentation and laboratory results suggest acute myeloid leukemia (AML), which is associated with a translocation between chromosomes 15 and 17. Myeloperoxidase is a marker often used to confirm the diagnosis of AML. The other options (B, C, and D) are not typically used in the diagnosis of AML.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The description of the patient’s laboratory studies and genetic analysis point towards acute promyelocytic leukemia (APL), a subtype of acute myeloid leukemia (AML) characterized by the t(15;17) translocation. APL cells are known to stain positive for myeloperoxidase. The other options are associated with other types of leukemia or cell types.
